commentBody:
Fun but fast Friday.

MOO
This was my fastest Friday time of the year so far.  And with only one more to go, it's probably a lock.

The grid looked daunting and was fun to fill, but it went by too fast. The three long entries in the middle solved especially quickly, but I thought all the long entries were enjoyable. So glad Henry was talked out of Dr Doofenshmirtz!
Such a fresh puzzle...I loved the clever misdirection of the clues.
Nice clueing, but this was too easy with too many black squares. 4/10

Deb, 
Rest. Rest. Rest.  Hopeful you ‚Äòll feel better very soon.

This was one of my fastest solves for a Friday, and I definitely felt it was very much on the easy side. The spanners all felt familiar and filled in quickly. Definitely a fun one, and a nice break.

Thanks, Henry!

This is the opposite of the Sunday puzzle that caused so much controversy. You can tell from the long spans in the grid design that it is an extra level of difficulty for the constructor, yet the puzzle has a sense of the ease and elegance. There was a bit of common glue but the clueing had some nice twists.
I wonder if they pull out an easy one just to calm the mob after a couple of rough days.
Echoing other comments, this was a new Friday PB (but such a fun puzzle)! FWIW I would have liked to see Doof in the puzz.
I liked the long spanners, but it was a quick one for a Friday.

Congratulations on a fun and zippy NYT debut, Mr. Josephson!

I especially liked the freshness of the four 15-letter answers in the top and bottom of the grid. 

Good luck with the remainder of your studies!
Feel better Deb! And thank you for the column despite your multi-symptom illness.

Agree with folks that it sidled along quickly. And a virtuoso puzzle with matching double-spanners and a lovely long triple stack in the center. RHEA being is the mother of GAIA, nice touch up top. Other nice touches: Top Seeded with Marijuana Leaves; the master of disguises saying, I'd like to remain anonymous...if I don't, I'd have to kill you; Unicorn Startups & Golden Spike (as in a spike in earnings might be called a golden spike); the Canadian Esso/Expos combo; the sound of Palau and Joao, as in Gilberto, as in when the Girl from Ipanema passes each one she passes goes: ahhhh...

(in a reply to this I'm gonna paste as much of the wonderful Nerudo Ode to Tuna as I can fit. It's one of his many odes (the most famous being an ode to his socks) that I think are among his best, most magically surrealist and heartfelt poems.

I was hoping for a tough puzzle to fall asleep with (also fighting respiratory demons) but, here I am.  No fault of this fine debut.  Took some time to check out the answers I was gifted from the crossings and the favorite is 57D, [Org. with towers].   Hint, it's not the FAA.   

Some strong talent here and hope to see more.
Sorry you are under the weather, Deb. Take care of yourself and get better soon!
12 seconds off my Friday best. Probably would have beaten it if I wasn't distracted. (Did the puzzle while watching the trailers before "The Brutalist")

I don‚Äôt like to say a particular puzzle was easy (everyone‚Äôs experience is different), but this one sure felt easy to me, *and* on my wavelength.  Friday PB, and fastest time this week except for Monday.

This one hit just right for me. A couple of AHA moments, smiles as I puzzled the long crosses, and a time at 90% of my average. 

Thanks, 
I‚Äôd sign here but I prefer anonymity.

Wishing Deb a speedy recovery. 

Puzzle was a good early morning Friday.
That was an amusing 10 minute pastime‚Ä¶. Like the railroad reference, the shorter clues really revealed the long stacks without much effort.  Fun!

Whenever I see long strings of white space my heart sinks a bit - I never expect to be able to get them without a lot of crosses. This turned out to be right up my alley, though! Fun long answers, and the short ones were nice and punchy, not too hard to get.

Thanks to John Ezra for pasting in the Ode to Tuna. What a beautiful, sad poem about an unexpected subject.
I wish you a speedy recovery!

As others have noted, very zippy. That left plenty of time to enjoy the ode to the tuns, thanks JohnEzra and find this Prince video to post, which I'm compelled to do whenever Willing and ABLE appear in the puzzle. And a shout out to the tower clue and fill. https://youtu.be/3Apk2Qr9yVc?si=MT8fiyX5ORqU337-
Wednesday-level of difficulty makes for an early Christmas gift: More time to plow through the 11,350 puzzles in the archive.
I solved it very quickly but it felt like there were a lot of very soft, not quite right clues.

45D The sun emerging from the clouds at exactly the right time happened to me at this April‚Äôs total solar eclipse, my third, which I observed from the chimpanzee habitat at the Dallas Zoo.  I reasoned that if I couldn‚Äôt see the sun, I could still observe what the animals did.  The sun emerged just before totality.  I didn‚Äôt see  the chimpanzees do anything that was a definite reaction. When I observed the 2017 eclipse from Stanley, Idaho, we had clear skies.  There were cows in the distance and lots of dogs immediately around. I didn‚Äôt see any of the cows react but the dogs‚Äô reactions were all over the place, from nothing noticeable, to shaking and vomiting but very quickly recovering.  At an elevation of 6290 ft, the temperature plunge was dramatic. My first total solar eclipse was in February 1979 and my father and I saw it from a plane chartered for the purpose. It was the only way that we had much of a chance of clear skies. I remember the shadow speeding across the tops of the clouds.  Breathtaking!  Each one is a fond memory.  

Feel better, Deb.  Hope you‚Äôre well enough to self-medicate with a bit of chocolate.

Fun crossword that kept me moving at a steady, if not zippy, rate. Only sliced 90 secs of my average time. 

I think I read someone did it in 10mins. Crikey, who are these crossword geniuses? Then again, I only started in May. Calma, Sebastian! Keep sidling along, you'll get there.

Enjoyable though it was a bit tougher for me than other commenters. I couldn‚Äôt get DOLMA (never heard of it) because I was convinced 53A was ‚Äúorbs‚Äù instead of LOBS.  I had ‚Äúfaa‚Äù for AAA because I was thinking of aircraft control towers being overseen by the faa. I still haven‚Äôt clicked on AAA ü§™.  That with what would become ELLY gives an idea of the mess I‚Äôd made of the lower third of the puzzle.

However, the long answers were familiar enough to help me untangle the bottom section. I liked REMAINANONYMOUS helping me at the bottom. The top long ones came pretty easily, too.

Something funny about people whose names are JO√ÉO here in Portugal (every other man‚Äôs name btw). I have had *several* of them independently and haughtily assert to me that I, a native English speaker, could never pronounce their name correctly. I proceed to say it properly. Their response 100% of the time? *Oh.* Then they move on to the business at hand without acknowledging my prowess with the nasality of the word üíÖüèæ! I laugh out loud now when it happens.

Have a great day everyone except JO√ÉOs üòú!
Easy for a Friday.
Sometimes it just seems to go your way. Completed in roughly half my average time.

Oh, towers! Not towers! 

Probably a bit under my average but definitely not as easy for me as it sounds like it was for some of you.

I have to remember GAIA and ODEA. Those are always tricky for me and I‚Äôm finding they‚Äôre somewhat frequent visitors on the weekends. (But I did fill in LICIT right away this time!)

Don‚Äôt think I ever realized SNOT NOSED means inexperienced. Always thought it meant something like ‚Äúchildishly bratty‚Äù. TIL

Thanks for the fun puzzle and congrats on your debut, Henry Josephson! Get well soon, Deb!

A well crafted puzzle, fun to work, and for me, not the slam dunk others experienced, but no look-ups necessary, and very satisfying. The "Girl from Impanema" gave me JOAO, the Portuguese for John, remembering the beautiful recording by Joao Gilberto, Astrud Gilberto and Stan Getz. Thank you, Henry, for that unintentional gift and congratulations on your NY Times debut. Deb, this is an awful time to be sick in bed. You were brave to drag yourself to the computer to offer some guidance to the needy, and you deserve a gold star for that. I find telehealth visits to be useless, but better than dragging in to the doc's office. Have you done any home testing? If not, maybe you should. Keep us posted on recovery. Sleep well. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c5QfXjsoNe4

Thanks for the Tom Stoppard R&G reference!

‚ÄúEternity is a terrible thought. I mean, where‚Äôs it going to end?‚Äù

Feel better, Deb!

A browser glitch ate my long comment. TLDR version: easy short answers made the spanners easy and TATAR was a gimme - TATARs featured prominently in Polish history, both as enemies and allies, their horse archers Poland's bane and boon.

Fun, though quick, but bonus points for turning my thoughts to Pablo Neruda, whose poetry carries one‚Äôs souls over the highest and the lowest tides of life. Here‚Äôs my favorite in William O‚ÄôDaly‚Äôs translation:

I have four dogs to declare:
one is already buried in the garden,
two others keep me on my toes,
tiny wild
destroyers,
with thick paws and hard canines
like needles of stones.
And one scruffy dog,
aloof,
fair-haired in her gracious manner.
No one hears her smooth golden steps
or her distant presence.
She barks only late at night
at certain phantoms,
so that just a few chosen hidden persons
hear her on the roads
or in other dark places.

Another finely crafted New York Times Crossword debut. Thanks Henry!
I circled back a few times and figured everything out in my usual manner, but not in record time. A bit tricky but never did I feel duped.
Deb, wishing you a speedy recovery, and thanks for delivering your commentary in spite of your terrible ailment.

This feels like a beginner‚Äôs ‚Äúcrossword vocabulary‚Äù question, but Deb refers to ‚Äúthree fabulous double stacks.‚Äù I see two, and a staggered set of three across entries in the middle. Do you generally refer to a stack only if it includes entries of equal length?

"Hey! Look at my mineral deposit!"
"Wow, would you get a lode of this guy?"

("Ore not.")
You were very generous to give us so much of your time, Deb, especially when you are so under the weather.  I hope you have some chicken soup to help you get through this.
Very fun! I don't usually get much on Fridays, but this one charmed me and breezed by.  Will be interested to see if regulars find it "too easy for a Friday."

I don‚Äôt find this as easy as most, (no surprise) but  really enjoyed it, especially the long entries.  I was surprised it was a debut and look forward to more from  Henry.

Adding my best wishes to Deb, such a miserable time to feel poorly.
Deb, you sound like you‚Äôre way beyond even chicken soup. Thanks for thinking of us while you‚Äôre so ill and get better soon. FWIW, the puzzle was a delight. Bon courage.
I finished this puzzle while my wife was waiting for her Starbucks at the airport. I think that‚Äôs more reflective of the Starbucks line than the ease of the puzzle though. Fun debut!

This was a fun one. Close to a Friday best for me, too, but I'm not complaining.

The spanners and stacks were fun, not immediately obvious. There seemed to be a lot of three-letter answers, but I only noticed one that's here all the time--I'm looking at you, SSN!--so they never felt routine or trite.

I had ICUS before SPAS, I really enjoyed the misdirection for AAA and ATM, and the juxtaposition of SER and ETRE (although ESTAR would also have been nice).

For some reason I was out of bed by 5:00 this morning, so I had time for a harder one, but this was still fun.

Thanks!

THE GOLDEN SPIKE shows up today, while just yesterday, I was beginning to put together a playlist of the train songs in my collection. Billy Bragg and Joe Henry The L&N Don't Stop Here Anymore https://youtu.be/GtlXwj80OWM?si=Q6tvG5amTj1fNtWJ

Nice puzzle. Not all that easy for me, of course (hi suejean), and cheated some, but still some nice 'aha' moments as things dawned on me from the crosses. Great to see a new constructor. Imagine we'll be seeing a lot more from Mr. Josephson. And, of course my puzzle find today. A Wednesday from October 19, 1994 by D.J. Listort. Three theme answers in that one. Clues and answers: 20a: "With 34-Across, one example of 51-Across" THESIXTHSHEIKS 34a: "See 20-Across" SIXTHSHEEPSSICK 51a: "Difficult articulations" TONGUETWISTERS Don't recall another one like that, and I've actually tried saying 20a and 34a aloud a few times and indeed it is a quite a tongue-twister (give it a try). Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/19/1994&g=51&d=A I'm done. ...
Really enjoyed this puzzle: No obscure rappers, just clever cluing. Congrats!

I started this one last night and was moving along at a reasonable pace, but I hit a brick wall in the upper third.  I gradually got the NE, but even with LEAVES and STARTUPS in place, i still couldn‚Äôt see the spanners.  I was thinking classically and couldn‚Äôt get past the obviously incorrect laurel leaves.  I finally had to shut it down and hope that a night‚Äôs sleep would get me over my puzzle block.  Morpheus worked his wonders and upon awakening MARIJUANALEAVES seemed clear the down crosses fell into place giving me UNICORNSTARTUPS.  I liked that LICIT crossed MARIJUANALEAVES.

I got my first Friday gold star today!  I‚Äôve always had trouble with puzzles with multiple long crosses but this one seemed to click. My only trouble area was the NW corner.  Took me a while to work through it as I had LIMIT instead of LICIT.
Wow, just wow! Looking forward to seeing your puzzles appear here soon. Congratulations on your debut, Henry J!

While not the toughest Friday, this was no walk in the park for me.  The long spanners up top had me guessing for a bit. 

To be a true SNOT NOSE, you have to be young, inexperienced *and* think you know everything.  Being young and inexperienced is not enough.  I'm not young enough to be SNOT NOSED, but that's my opinion, and I'm sticking (ha ha) to it.

It's a pity that so little of Erik Satie's music is known, apart from the lovely but over-played Gymnop√©dies and Gnossiennes. Here's a Nocturne, from late in his career, performed by the great Jean-Yves Thibaudet. (Oddly, I've always associated this piece with Christmas Eve): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QWLKJSh7Zgk Uncharacteristic lack of sarcasm, from either Erik or myself.

Get better, Deb.

Shall I clutch my pearls about the vulgar SNOT NOSED?
At least, that'll keep 'em out of the way of the snot trail.

And as cliched as 56A is, you can't say that on social media these days. The emus probably wouldn't allow it here, either.
K*ll-joys.

A lively puzzle, with some impish Friday cluing.
At first I had "raw talent" rather than snot nosed. So I had water or wager as 33D pool contents. And Warhol did multiple paintings of a soup "can" as well as MAO.

Thanks, Henry. I do have some thoughts about AI governance, but I think that cat's out of the bag.

Strands #292
‚ÄúMorning morsel‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üîµ

Biting my morning morsel.
Can't we just assume that people have already done the Strands puzzle before they come to the Wordplay comments? It's hard to get any real discussion going when we have to bite our tongues until after the "view all replies" button.

Greatest Friday puzzle ever!!!
(*sniff*)

But seriously:
Spanners support super-slick split-second solve.

Oi!!
Deb, I‚Äôm so sorry you‚Äôre feeling awful.
I‚Äôm gonna just hope you‚Äôre getting it over with
and the rest of the season will be 
healthy, hearty, happy and holiday heaven.

( And hydrated. Please hydrate? )

Puzzle? 
Oh yeah,
there was a puzzle‚Ä¶

I cannot find a nit to pick.
Pick a nit? I cannot.

Haven‚Äôt read comments yet, but
this ‚Äòun felt like every letter 
deserved to be there. 
Every letter was born there!

For newer solvers who
may feel this level of difficulty is daunting,
I‚Äôm here to tell you,

I was stuck.
Like, up-to-my-knees *stuck.*

Had entries filled all over but
soooo
much
white‚Ä¶

Then, my morning eyes glanced back at
[Contents of a pool]
and GENES jumped out!

Those few letters opened up the entire grid.
It finished itself so quickly I think I giggled.

It‚Äôs *not* about knowing all the answers!
It‚Äôs guessing, sussing, squinting, 
re-reading the clues,
plopping in letters, deleting them and 
then plopping them in again!

This was lovely.
I‚Äôm thinking it‚Äôs gotta be a Friday POY contender, right?

Thank you Henry!

( and Deb‚Ä¶hydrate )
Great Fri debut. Congrats and thanks!

One of the great pleasure pings of solving is when there‚Äôs a long answer in the grid with a few crosses, and, in a flash, you suddenly realize what the full answer is.  Truly, isn‚Äôt that a great moment?

There was much opportunity for that today through a combination of 10 answers with nine letters or more, and sufficient footholds crossing them. For me, a glorious pingathon.  

This was buttressed by spark in the answer set, with 11 answers that have appeared but twice or less in the Times puzzle over its 80+ years.

A lit-up grid filled with pleasure-bursts ‚Äì well, that‚Äôs a sweet devil of a puzzle, and in a NYT debut puzzle, no less. Wow!

I loved the originality as well, with two answers that are debuts not only in the Times but in all the major venues -- REMAIN ANONYMOUS and MARIJUANA LEAVES -- and [Harsh sentences?] for TONGUE TWISTERS, a most lovely clue for it that has never been used anywhere before.

Henry, it‚Äôs clear you are ABLE, and I‚Äôm hoping you‚Äôre willing as well, to create more.  Thank you so much for this day-brightening jewel!

If I were a speed solver, I'd say this was one of the fastest Fridays ever in my many decades of NYTXW solving. But even though I found this unbelievably easy, I also appreciated the long entries for their cleverness, as well as the misdirection of some of the clues, e.g. [Tower]. Too often the old curmudgeon in me is annoyed by debut constructors young enough to be my grandchildren, but not this time. No rappers, slang, or actor of the moment, and only a couple of sports-related clues. That's my speed! 

Having said that, I'm grateful to the editors who thoughtfully disallowed Dr. Doofenshmirtz and Phineas and Ferb, whoever any of them are. I would have not been a happy camper.

Deb, wishing you quick healing and lotsa latkes along with that much-needed chicken soup.
Rather odd. Bottom 2/3 played likre a sober Monday and the top 1/3 played like a tripped-out Saturday. Bit of a unicorn crossword. Nice debut Henry!

Please take good care of yourself and get well soon, Miss Deb! 

Today‚Äôs puzzle was surprisingly easy for a Friday, but nonetheless delightful. I looked for a pattern amongst the long answers, but they were just long‚Äîand fun! TIL Satie, unicorn startups, and Joao.

For those that solve the puzzle,
Wordle,
Connections, and 
Spangram,

did today feel like
the editors got together and said,

‚ÄúThe holidays are stressful.
They‚Äôre all stressed. Let‚Äôs make today just‚Ä¶fun.‚Äù

Just me?
Feel better soon, Deb. And congratulations, Henry. That was so much fun.
Rest, recuperate and feel better, Deb!‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π Kudos and thanks for rising to the occasion, as ever. Hope someone is bringing you medical-grade chicken soup (with loads of ginger)!

Deb, its clear in the comments today how greatly you are adored, which gladdens me, because I‚Äôm a stalwart member of your fan club as well.  Strongly wishing you a speedy turnaround, a quick return to normalcy, back to your extraordinary self.

This would have been a fine "themeless Wednesday" puzzle. But with *eight* easily discerned long entries---whose letters occupy more than half the grid---I found it too easy for a Friday. Don't know how others feel, but having multiple long phrases makes a puzzle much easier---not harder---for me to solve.

Congrats on the debut. The long entries were all solid, and some of the five-letter verticals were interesting: LICIT, PALAU, TATAR, SATIE, DOLMA.

Way to upstage the constructor Deb! :)

Henry, call me for my lecture on compounding error as it is a blend of data science, actual science and philosophy.

Fine puzzle except for the part where we had tone for TANG.

Get well Deb, take two MARIJUANA LEAVES and call me in the morning.... I mean I am a Dr.

Thank you Henry

I loved the fresh cluing! 'Marijuana leaves' made me smile. Thank you, Henry Josephson!  I hope to see more puzzles by you.

Get well soon, Deb!  (Lots of fluids and rest!)
Impressive debut! I loved the vertical answer for carte blanche. Hope Deb feels better soon. I‚Äôve got a cold too but it‚Äôs not so bad but it does stink to be sick around the holidays.

Aw, I would've loved to see Dr. Doofenshmirtz in the puzzle! Nevertheless, this was a great debut. Congrats!

And feel better soon, Deb! Everyone is sick right now, it seems. I'm just getting over Covid myself. Did you know Covid can come with pink eye? Fun times.
Ugh!  towers, not towers! (English is hard)

Great puzzle!   Loved it!   It's a busy time so I had to solve in little fits and starts, which helped my brain come up with alternate readings of those tricky clues!
Thanks to Constructor and Editors for a crunchy fun puzzle-- and thanks for leaving out Dr Doofen-whatzzit-- I was able to solve with no lookups. (But I promise to look that up!)

And Deb, please rest and we hope you get better soon!
Every one of these spanners was a burst of joy. Great puzzle!
Feel better soon, Deb!!!!

As a lifelong Cincinnati Reds fan, I was thrilled to see ELLY De La Cruz make an appearance in today's puzzle!

Congrats, Henry, on your debut!
Good one today. Impressive debut. Hope to see more from Henry!

A "bit" (usually metal) comes straight from the horse's mouth.  It is part of the bridle.  The reins, typically leather, are attached to the side of the bridle and never go into the mouth or are straight from.  The horse would gnaw through the leather if they were straight from the mouth.
Feel better, Deb. I had a hot flash this morning!!! I'm way past the age for one of these.....The puzzle should give me time to move  past whatever is ,,,,,,
I think you all ran Saturday's Crossword a day early.

Oh, that kind of "high art." The kind best viewed with a black light. I was thinking of Michelangelo painting the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. And because I watch the business news in the morning, the top stack had me thinking of Canopy Growth. I don't know if they were proper unicorns, but their ticker symbol is WEED, which I find highly amusing. "Siri, what's the price of WEED today?"

That was a relief. After yesterday's blizzard of sports, TV and kids' films, just a couple of sports clues for me to work around, with EXPOS being fillable as soon as I saw -XP--.
Never heard of UNICORNSTARTUPS so it took a lo-o-ong time to figure out the first word there.
But very much enjoyed that one.
Firm but Fair! Great debut. And is your Provost "Katie" Baicker from Montgomery NJ?

Deb, feel better.  Sleep, gargle salt water....

What a great puzzle! Over before I could believe it.  Great fill and wonderful long answers.  More puzzles, mr Josephson, and best luck with your studies as you submit puzzles.
For of all sad words of tongue or pen, the saddest are these: 'It might have been!'
Didn't break my record but still blazed through this one in under 8 minutes. Fun fill and I especially liked 14A
Came so close. Had never heard of a "unicorn startup" and didn't know the Portuguese for John.
About 1/3 of my average time, but I should be working anyway. Excellent Friday debut. Lots of long answers, and enough to puzzle out.  TGIF!

Deb,
Paxlovid is the chicken soup of our decade.
Get some if you can.
This is the best puzzle they‚Äôve published in a while! Great, intuitive long answers. More of this!
Fantastic Wednesday puzzle.

Deb, it's amazing you were able to pull off writing as much as you did, feeling as you do. But...even warriors need rest (and chicken soup) sometimes. ;-)

Sending you best wishes for a quick and full recovery!
A softball if there ever was one.  The editors are making amends for last Sunday's disaster.
Really enjoyed this one, a good level of difficulty for a Friday and some neat answers and clues
delightfully cruncy, all clues are fair, and using answers I've not (or can't remember) ever seeing before.  Perfection with a slog slowly coming together.

That was ....fun...ish.  I kept reminding myself that Fridays are Themeless.
It was interesting...  if lightweight.
The long Across pairs seemed to be loosely theme-adjacent.
And 44A was quite a surprise.

Also, an MLB player named ELLY sent me to Google, and Voila! a Cincinnati Red!!  That was once Our Team (Big Red Machine's halcyon days, sigh.)

Wanted FOO Fighters!   
Surprise of the Day:  SATIE as influential for Ravel and Debussy!  Guessed it off the ---ie,  Nice factoid!
Time to make the lasagna noodles.  TTFN!

My most favourite crossword yet. Not easy but not impenetrable.
Except I need help with:
5 down - clue and solution
39 D - SSN
Please.

PS Why all the references to chicken soup - where does that come from? I had vaguely heard of it, didn't realise it was quite so popular.

I enjoyed doing this puzzle, but I can't see the reason for an exclamation mark for the 60 down clue.  

Have a good weekend and enjoy filling in your grids in the best of health and spirit.
Nice debut, man!  Super fun solve.

I set a new personal Friday best on this, I was right in sync with the constructor. Thank you, Henry, for a fun puzzle. It's always impressive when there are so many entries of such length without them becoming a slog. Loved it!

This is in reply to Min:

This type of clue which breaks the general rule of equivalence:  a noun clues a noun, a verb clues a verb, etc.  Singular clues singular; past clues past, etc.  The most basic clues are approximate synonyms or equivalents.  To point out some of the simplest from today's offering:

[Allowed] for LICIT
[Triumph] for WIN
[Sharpness] for TANG

Some clues are examples or more complete definitions, maintaining parallelism in part of speech and specific form:

[Move like a crab] for SIDLE
[The sun emerging from the clouds at exactly the right time, say] for OMEN

But clues like the one for 60D are different. The answer tells what "there" (or more usually, "it") is in the clue, often with some misdirection:

[Stay there!] clues INN because an INN is where you can stay.  In addition, "Stay there!" is usually used to mean "Don't come any closer" or "Stay where you are, I'm coming to you."

A previous clue with "there!" was 3/14/20, when [Refuse to go there!] clued DUMP, and on 11/17/18, [Hang in there!] clued CLOSET.  

To make things more confusing, often such clues are of the standard type, such as (7/1/23) ["You there!"] clues HEY, and (3/28/20) ["Well, looky there!"] clues OHO.  How can you tell the difference?  Note that these equivalency clues have quotation marks to indicate similar things one could say aloud, whereas the misdirects have no quotes.

The more common word used in such clues is "it" instead of "there".  Some examples in a reply.

This must be an inside joke because‚Ä¶
Tang is inside the handle thus can‚Äôt relate to sharpness. 
Emu is only vaguely related to Rhea in that it is flightless. Not same family or order (or class?). I‚Äôm guessing this one is a crossword norm but‚Ä¶ ‚Äúflightlessness arose independently multiple times via parallel evolution‚Äù - Wikipedia Palaeognathae

This is the rest of the post from about 20 minutes ago.  For some reason, my posts are not posting in a timely fashion now:

From last Fri:  [Put a lid on it!] for HATRACK.

From earlier this year:
10/17: [Don't you forget it!] for ALAMO.
8/10: [Don't mention it!] for TABOO.
6/16: [Think about it!] for IDEA.
5/22: [This guy gets it!] for DONEE.
4/6: [Book it!] for RESERVED SEAT.
2/9: [Suck it!] for STRAW.

And from earlier:
11/24/23: [Spill it!] for GOSSIP.
10/11/23: [Stuff it!] for PEPPER.
9/16/23: [Skip it!] for STONE.
9/15/23: [Darn it!] for SOCK.
9/8/23: [Skip it!] for ROPE.
8/2/23: [Ewe got it!] for WOOL.
7/23/23: [Run for it!] for OFFICE, 

and perhaps the best puzzle for this list:

7/19/23: [Deal with it!] for DECK OF CARDS,

I‚Äôm always struck by the diversity of solving reports. Usually when I have tons of fun or cruise through a rebus, there are a thousand tortured comments from the drama department. Then on a day like today when it takes me multiple visits and much late night gnashing of teeth to solve, I feel like an idiot reading all the comments about how easy it was. (Or, heaven forfend, the puzzle was published on the ‚Äúwrong‚Äù day. Sigh.)

All I can say is how lucky we all are to be here every day, how much I enjoy the puzzles and all comments, and how grateful I am for the constructors, columnists, and games crew that make it all possible. Get well soon, Deb, and Happy Holidays to everyone else out there!

Ode to a Large Tuna in the Market

                      -- Pablo Neruda
                           Robin Robertson, trans.

Here,   
among the market vegetables,
this torpedo
from the ocean   
depths,   
a missile   
that swam,
now   
lying in front of me
dead.

Surrounded
by the earth's green froth   
‚Äîthese lettuces,
bunches of carrots‚Äî
only you   
lived through
the sea's truth, survived
the unknown, the
unfathomable
darkness, the depths   
of the sea,
the great   
abyss,
le grand ab√Æme,
only you:   
varnished
black-pitched   
witness
to that deepest night.

Only you:
dark bullet
barreled   
from the depths,
carrying   
only   
your   
one wound,
but resurgent,
always renewed,
locked into the current,
fins fletched
like wings
in the torrent,
in the coursing
of
the
underwater
dark,
like a grieving arrow,
sea-javelin, a nerveless   
oiled harpoon.

Dead
in front of me,
catafalqued king
of my own ocean;
once   
sappy as a sprung fir
in the green turmoil,
once seed
to sea-quake,
tidal wave, now
simply
dead remains;
in the whole market
yours   
was the only shape left
with purpose or direction
in this   
jumbled ruin
of nature;
you are   
a solitary man of war
among these frail vegetables,
your flanks and prow
black   
and slippery
as if you were still
a well-oiled ship of the wind,
the only
true
machine
of the sea: unflawed,
undefiled,   
navigating now
the waters of death.

In Poland when I'm sick I'm not required to work, and I get 80% of my salary for the first 33 days of illness in a given year. It's not really good when a sick employee is expected to work, is it?

@Andrzej My experience is that working when sick is more self-inflicted than required. Not all employees in the US have paid sick time, but professionals typically do, at 100%. The US work ethic has evolved in my lifetime into what I consider a very unhealthy emphasis on work at all costs. As I'm sure you know, the safety net has a lot of holes, and here's another consequence.

@Nora

@Andrzej

Not to mention the culture surrounding sick days: toughing it out and going to work when you are sick is actually seen as virtuous by many people here! @Nancy J. I‚Äôm sympathetic to people who can‚Äôt afford to stay home, but I‚Äôm also sympathetic to those whose health makes even the common cold extremely risky.  Working while sick may cause serious harm or even death to those with certain medical conditions.  Certainly, we have to assume some risk in order to venture out in the world at all, but avoidable risks shouldn‚Äôt be necessary in a rightly-structured society of compassionate people.

@Nora 

"The US work ethic has evolved in my lifetime into what I consider a very unhealthy emphasis on work at all costs." 

In terms of workers, I think that depends a bit on the job -- as a tech worker, being a "workaholic" seemed part of the job requirement -- but also an attitude that adjusts from one generation to the next. As young Gen-X, we were called "slackers"; then apparently Millennials wanted quality of life over big careers, and I believe the same is now being said about Gen-Z... 

As for the employers, I have experienced a gradual loosening of the work-at-all-costs time off positioning. In my early 20's at a brokerage firm, for example, we were given only 6 sick days a year!! A greater understanding plus easing up of work from home restrictions has helped a lot regarding what @Cindy mentioned down-thread...

@Linda Jo

I'm gen x/Millenial and I eat any of the following in the morning: hummus, baba ghanoush, halloumi cheese toast with fresh or roasted tomatoes, kefir and a banana, bread with peanut butter and honey, sardines or salmon with bread and olives. @Andrzej 
The only brand name in the bunch is Cheerio(s).
All the rest are shapes or forms of cereal. Like Corn Flakes or sugar pops. And different manufacturers made similar cereals.  Your head would probably explode in the cereal aisle of a big suburban supermarket. Or the snack aisle or the soda aisle. Or any aisle really.
For years and years I only shopped at a food Coop in my neighborhood, which had limited space and products. I would get overwhelmed if in a regular supermarket.

@Eric Hougland -- I don't mean to cause you or John any problems, but you HAVE NO IDEA HOW HARD I FIND IT TO TRACK DOWN anything in the comments section of this blog!!!!!  The scrolling system was invented by the Marquis of Sade.  It's like finding a needle in a haystack.  Here are some of the things I contend with.  YMMV.

1) If there are more than 100 comments, the F function no longer works.  Sometimes if you scroll down far enough it starts to work again, but how far is enough...?

2) You can only scroll using the name of the commenter on the F function.  If I type in "Puzzle of the Year" nothing at all will happen.

3) My own particular problem:  There's another Nancy (J) on the blog who usually posts above me so that her comment will come up and not mine.  At least 50% of the time if I've waited longer than 2-3 hours to check a post of mine, I WILL NEVER SET EYES ON MY OWN COMMENT AGAIN.

I give finding John Ezra's next solicitation for POY nominations about a 15% chance of my ever seeing it.  And that's perhaps over-optimistic.  So please take this nomination down, Eric -- there may be no second chance.  Thanks so much!

@Nancy 

1. False.  Start at the beginning (or end) and scroll to the other end.  Then do your search.  It will find all single strings that you search for except those buried in the "View More Replies"
2. False.  Your search results will include all the hits on your search string, not just search strings that are commenter names.
3. When you enter a comment, and before submitting, if you check the box that says "Email me when my comment is published and if a journalist responds." then you will get an email with a link that will take you directly to your comment.
The results are based on using Ctrl-F on a PC.

@Nancy

I was just coming here to mention it!

@Jim, correct. I cannot be among a minority that uses iPad and iPhone. Searching the page on iOS does not search the comments, only the body text of the article. I believe this is the reason for the many repeated mentions of the same issues, questions, etc.

@Nancy 

I sympathize with you about how hard it is to find a specific comment here. 

Let‚Äôs compromise: I‚Äôll take this nomination up with John Ezra and Cat Lady Margaret, and if two of us agree to include it, it‚Äôs in. 

But you will have to be on the lookout for another nominations solicitation from John, and when you see it, you‚Äôll renominate this puzzle. 

I‚Äôm not trying to be difficult. I just want to be fair to everyone who wants to nominate a puzzle. 

Thanks.

@CCNY --OMG -- if only I'd known this ten years ago!!!!!!!!!!  It will help you too!

Jim's 3rd bit of advice to me about the email with the link that will take me directly to my comment has been hiding in plain sight for all these years.  I DO receive the email from the NYT and I always delete it and I never have thought to look at the link at the bottom.  Now I will and, hopefully I will never suffer again trying to find my own comment.  Yay -- and thank you, Jim.  

It won't help me find anyone else's comment though.  Jim's other suggestion about scrolling through from top to bottom or from bottom to top strikes me as, well, slightly sadistic.  There is absolutely no way I intend to spend my life that way.

I suspect, @CCNY that, like me, you are a tech-challenged person.  This comments section really wasn't designed for the likes of us.

@Nancy 

Starting at the top of the comments sorted in newest to oldest order, I used the PageDown key to scroll to the end.  It took 14 seconds.

I appreciate it, Eric.  Thanks so much.  I imagine that Laura and Katherine will appreciate it even more.

If I see another call to nominate, I certainly will be happy to do so.  If I don't and therefore can't, then I won't.  So we'll both find out on the same day whether I saw the request or not.

I wish I were tech-proficient.  I would offer my services free of charge on how to make this comments section user-friendly and easy to navigate.  If I were REALLY tech-savvy, I doubt it would take me more than 15 minutes.  I wonder why one of the many computer coding whizzes associated with the NYT hasn't offered to do so.  Someone like Jeff Chen could reprogram the system in the blink of an eye, I'm pretty sure.

@Nancy 

I am tech-proficient, a tech designer and even was part of the team who designed the WSJ comments functionality when it first launched about 15 years ago. I find the NYT commenting functionality atrociously outdated and painful to use! 

The "find in page" not-finding issue occurs because only a section of the comments loads at a time -- thus why Jim is prompting to scroll all the way through first. Once there are a few hundred comments, good luck with that! Also, any replies for which you have to hit the "View All" button are not loaded and thus not searched... 

My comment may be a little too technical itself -- but rest assured, the struggle is real! 

(And imagine, it's the same across almost all of the NYT!!)

Nancy, to find specifically John Ezra's comments more quickly, do this:

Under "Reader Picks" and "All," to the right, there's an option of scrolling newest to oldest, or oldest to newest.
Pick oldest.
Because JE usually posts the night before the puzzle's date, you'll have a lot fewer comments to scroll through to get to his.

Hope this helps for POY nominations.

5D

Surpass, as in the verb to surpass. The clue refers how the word is made up of sur and pass.

SSN, the American ID number that apparently everybody has but you can't let anybody know it because they will be able to steal your identity or something. We don't have something like that in European countries, do we?

@Jane Wheelaghan My favourite medical journal article on the topic of chicken soup and upper respiratory tract infections is entitled, "Barbara, what's a nice girl like you doing writing an article like this? : the scientific basis of folk remedies for colds and flu" https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11035648/ It seems to have originated as a Jewish traditional remedy, going back to Maimonides. Having grown up in a staunchly Presbyterian bit of Scotland, I'd never heard of it until I started reading American books and watching American TV. My grandfather's cure for the common cold is more traditionally Scottish, involving a hat and a bottle of whisky. You go to bed, hang the hat on the bedpost, and drink the whisky until the hat starts to move around the room.

@Andrzej I've started to think that it makes sense. I'm miserable with a cold and don't want much of anything to eat, but chicken soup simply makes me feel less miserable. Today's puzzle was Chicken Soup for the recent Donald Trump week. Thanks! Keep 'em coming because we're going to need it!
@Andrzej IN Spain we do. NIE
@Andrzej I'm a dual citizen, so not certain, but you need to give an NIE for any employment, bank account, and taxes plus a host of other things. I doubt it's something you want other people to have.

@Andrzej 
Thanks! I remember now there was a clue about not giving this number to someone in a pub (unlike your phone number), which was incomprehensible to me. 
We have an NI - a national insurance number which  is not used often, it is given to an employer before starting a job and it's used for collecting your  taxes.  It's 2 letters and 6 numbers and I only remember the letters are YT - I use it so little. 

It's also used when you claim a pension or benefits, but it has to match your date of birth, address, bank account etc  etc. If you wanted to steal an identity you'd need a lot more information than the NI number. There is also a National Health service number, I don't think anyone remembers that number either! Now it's all on databases.

@Min I've noticed it's been a common motif in NYT puzzles especially, the ! indicates that the clue is likely the direct object of an excited phrase.

@Min 

This type of clue which breaks the general rule of equivalence:  a noun clues a noun, a verb clues a verb, etc.  Singular clues singular; past clues past, etc.  The most basic clues are approximate synonyms or equivalents.  To point out some of the simplest from today's offering:

[Allowed] for LICIT
[Triumph] for WIN
[Sharpness] for TANG

Some clues are examples or more complete definitions, maintaining parallelism in part of speech and specific form:

[Move like a crab] for SIDLE
[The sun emerging from the clouds at exactly the right time, say] for OMEN

But clues like the one for 60D are different. The answer tells what "there" (or more usually, "it") is in the clue, often with some misdirection:

[Stay there!] clues INN because an INN is where you can stay.  In addition, "Stay there!" is usually used to mean "Don't come any closer" or "Stay where you are, I'm coming to you."

A previous clue with "there!" was 3/14/20, when [Refuse to go there!] clued DUMP, and on 11/17/18, [Hang in there!] clued CLOSET.  

To make things more confusing, often such clues are of the standard type, such as (7/1/23) ["You there!"] clues HEY, and (3/28/20) ["Well, looky there!"] clues OHO.  How can you tell the difference?  Note that these equivalency clues have quotation marks to indicate similar things one could say aloud, whereas the misdirects have no quotes.

The more common word used in such clues is "it" instead of "there".  Some examples in a reply.
